concern:
I had an absolutely awful semester in regards to my grades. I took 5 classes and did either horribly or just enough to get by. At some point I just felt burnt out and didn’t go to class for 2-3 weeks. I had 18 absences in a single class. In another I stopped going after the 4th week. 

The last time I checked canvas I had passing grades in 4. But I’m not sure if that will reflect in my final grades. Normally it’s after you’ve missed the equivalent of two weeks of class you fail but I’ve missed more than that and passed before. 

Last semester I had my highest gpa yet and to see myself fail and crumble the following semester has been really disheartening. I’m not sure what to do for the following semester and what to do if it turns out I failed my classes this semester.

dialogue_total.statement: It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed. What has been causing you the most stress lately?
I've been most stressed by the overwhelming demands of my coursework and the burnout I've been feeling. It's been tough dealing with the disappointment in my academic progress.

It can be really tough to feel like you're not meeting your own expectations. It sounds like the workload is taking a toll on your energy and motivation. Is there anything you've tried so far to manage the stress and burnout?
I've tried attending therapy sessions to help cope with the stress. I've also made an effort to take short breaks from my routine to regain some energy.

It's great to hear that you've been proactive in seeking support and making time for self-care. Taking breaks can be really helpful in managing stress and avoiding burnout. Have there been any specific activities or hobbies you've found particularly helpful during those breaks?
I've found that going for short walks outside helps me clear my mind and recharge a bit. Listening to music during those breaks has also been a simple way to ease the fatigue and regain some focus.

It's wonderful to hear that you've found solace in nature and music during your breaks. Engaging with the outdoors and enjoying music can be very therapeutic and rejuvenating. It sounds like you've been able to find some relief from the stress through these activities. Have you considered incorporating these breaks into your daily routine as a preventative measure against burnout?

Yes, I've been thinking about making those walks and music sessions a regular part of my day to help ward off that overwhelming exhaustion. It could make a big difference in staying on top of things without hitting that wall again.

That's a great idea! Regularly scheduling self-care activities like walks and music sessions can be an effective way to manage stress and maintain a healthy balance in your life. It might also help you approach your coursework with renewed energy and focus. How would you go about making these breaks a consistent part of your daily routine?

I could start by setting specific times in my schedule, like a 15-minute walk after lunch and before dinner, to make it a habit. This way, I'll build in regular self-care to help maintain my focus and prevent future exhaustion.

It seems like you've got a solid plan in place! By scheduling regular breaks for self-care activities, you're taking a proactive approach to maintain your well-being and prevent burnout. This can have a positive impact on your academic progress and overall mental health. Would you like to discuss any potential challenges you might face in sticking to this new routine, and how you could overcome them?

Yes, I'd like to discuss potential challenges with sticking to this routine, as I worry about slipping back into old habits during busy periods. I think identifying simple strategies, like using reminders on my phone, could help me stay consistent and avoid that overwhelming exhaustion.

It's great that you're thinking ahead about potential challenges and considering strategies to overcome them. Setting phone reminders is an excellent way to stay on track with your self-care routine. Remember, it's important to be kind to yourself and allow for flexibility during particularly busy times. Staying mindful of your well-being and making adjustments as needed will contribute to your overall success. Feel free to reach out if you have any other concerns or would like to discuss further strategies. Until then, I wish you the best of luck, and I'm looking forward to hearing about your progress during our next session.
I'll make sure to use phone reminders for my self-care routine to prevent slipping back into exhaustion. Thanks for the support, and I'll look forward to sharing my progress next session.
